pros: Help desk jobs are generally pretty saturated on the East coast. I've applied to many help desk jobs and I can say that LVHN is one of the best places to start in IT. Second, the hourly rate is a bit higher than what you would get working for lesser known organizations in the Lehigh Valley. Other places were offering me in the 17-18 range. My base rate is 20.67 and since I work 2nd shift, I get a little extra on top of that for all hours past 430pm, raising my rate to 22.32/hour. This coming September, they will have us coming back to the office on a hybrid basis (2 days office, 3 days remote). I've been in the office only a handful of times (1st day orientation, pick stuff up, etc) as I started working after the pandemic. The office is very modern and well kept. I haven't had the chance to take part in them yet, but there are mandatory shadowing opportunities for us help desk people to get paired with a member of a different technology team to see a different side of the system. If you request it, LVHN will also provide you with free access to LinkedIn Learning. They do not pay for the cost of certifications, but they are already a lot better than other places.

pros:
One of the biggest employers in the Lehigh Valley and they know it. Good in the sense that everyone knows and recognizes where you work but bad in a lot of other ways. They have an ok image in the community but it is arguably declining because they are getting so big and can't keep up with the pace of their growth. 

Healthcare is a fast growing industry and the Lehigh Valley area is also fast growing so the experience gained here is ultimately good to take anywhere else. For RN's, the Magnet designated hospital status is really good to be apart of. 

Some benefits, like health care, are really good but others are a big miss - see the cons. 

People for the most part are nice, but there's reason to believe that everyone puts a smile on their face and stabs you behind your back - again, see the cons.
cons:
Culture culture culture... The company is really not what people think it is from the outside. This organization is the height of dysfunction if i ever saw it. I almost thought for a while that your department made a big difference in your experience but honestly am not sure. 

A lot of the people i've come across are unprofessional, cliquey and immature. It is like being back in high school and really gets annoying. Many of the managers and supervisors are amateurs. Don't expect any guidance out of them. They're mostly scared for their jobs and don't know how to manage or develop people.

It seems like they use their non profit designation when convenient to justify any thing they do to cut or limit employees benefits like giving low starting salaries and pathetic raises that aren't based on the work you actually do but some nonsense network wide goals that may not even have anything to do with your job. They are a $1 billion company and cry the blues like they are barely scraping by and actually ask employees to DONATE to them because they are a non profit. Give me a break! 

Health benefits are good with the exception being you have to go to a LVHN provider which isn't always the best since the ER wait times are god awful and also length to get an appointment with some providers. If you need proof of this just look at the complaints about wait times in the ER online.  

Holidays (5 or 6 of them to be exact which is basically nothing compared to most corporations) are included in PTO so it seems like you're getting 3 or 4 weeks but you're not getting all of it to use how you want it. In my entire career I have never had an employer include holidays into the time off. Sick time is separate but you'll always end up having way more than you'll ever be able to use. They have weird rules about when you can and can't use your PTO too at the end of the year. It's a joke. 

The wellness benefit that they give employees seems generous, $700 a year, but is a joke about how and what you can use it for. The programs that they offer are considerably cut back from what they tell you they are in the benefits brochure from HR and you have to use one of their gyms in order to get reimbursed for the gym membership. So it is questionable if it is even a benefit since a lot of employees dont even use it.

pros: Benefits not bad but you have to use LVH for prescriptions

Manager thinks you should come in even when you are sick. I worked in one of the practices LVH bought up and seems to me the only thing they care about is making money. IF your looking for a place that treats you like a person then LVHN is not for you or me anymore.
